verses.text: My son, pay attention to my wisdom; incline your ear to my understanding,
verses.comment: The Father's loving invitation here reflects the tradition of passing on wisdom, emphasizing a relationship much deeper than simple information—pointing to the importance of listening and obedience within the family and faith community.

verses.text: so that you may preserve discretion, and your lips may guard knowledge.
verses.comment: Discretion suggests not only personal prudence but also the guarding of divine truth, which is entrusted to believers for safekeeping and proclamation—a theme later echoed in Christ's warnings about careful stewardship of his teachings.

verses.text: For the lips of a forbidden woman drip honey, and her speech is smoother than oil;
verses.comment: The forbidden woman is an image of seductive temptation and spiritual danger, often interpreted as both literal adultery and spiritual infidelity to God.

verses.text: but in the end she is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a double-edged sword.
verses.comment: What seems attractive at first leads to poison and destruction, a timeless warning about sin’s deceptive allure and lasting consequences.

verses.text: Her feet go down to death; her steps take hold on Sheol.
verses.comment: A deeply spiritual warning: sin does not just wound—it leads to spiritual death (see James 1:15, Rom. 6:23).

verses.text: She does not ponder the path of life; her ways wander, and she does not know it.
verses.comment: Here is a warning about spiritual blindness—sin leads one astray, often without awareness. True wisdom allows us to discern the right path.

verses.text: Now then, my sons, listen to me, and do not turn aside from the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: The repetition of 'listen' highlights obedience and faithfulness—concepts foundational to spiritual growth and community.

verses.text: Keep your way far from her, and do not go near the door of her house,
verses.comment: Prudence here means avoiding the occasion of sin—an ancient principle, later taught by spiritual masters and encouraged for maintaining holiness.

verses.text: lest you give your honor to others and your years to the cruel one;
verses.comment: Sin has lasting effects—it steals dignity and life, drawing from the biblical understanding that holiness preserves not just the soul but honor and legacy.

verses.text: strangers will be filled with your wealth, and your hard work will go to the house of another.
verses.comment: Echoes of divine justice—resources can be lost through immorality, highlighting the link between spiritual and material stewardship.

verses.text: At the end of your life you will groan, when your flesh and your body are consumed,
verses.comment: This verse can be read both literally and spiritually—sin harms body and soul, and regret comes at the end. Compare Paul's teachings on sin’s consequences (Rom. 1:27).

verses.text: and you will say, 'How I hated instruction, and my heart despised correction!'
verses.comment: Rejection of wisdom leads to regret; a spiritual lesson about the necessity of humility and receptive obedience for salvation.

verses.text: I did not listen to the voice of my teachers or incline my ear to my instructors.
verses.comment: Scripture places great value on instruction through teaching authority, later expanded in the New Testament through Christ and his appointed leaders.

verses.text: I am at the verge of complete ruin in the midst of the assembly and congregation.
verses.comment: The mention of 'assembly and congregation' (the gathered community) indicates public consequences of private sin—implying the spiritual protection and accountability provided by the wider faith community.

verses.text: Drink water from your own cistern, flowing water from your own well.
verses.comment: A metaphor for marital fidelity, but also a spiritual image for the soul’s source of life in God’s wellspring, echoing Christ's teaching on living water (John 4:14).

verses.text: Should your springs overflow in the streets, streams of water in the public squares?
verses.comment: Implying the sacredness of marital intimacy—what is holy should not be given away lightly, following the biblical emphasis on sanctity.

verses.text: Let them be yours alone, and not shared with strangers.
verses.comment: A reaffirmation of exclusive covenantal relationship, paralleling teachings on God’s covenant fidelity to his people.

verses.text: Let your fountain be blessed, and rejoice in the wife of your youth.
verses.comment: Blessing upon marriage echoes God’s intended joy and sanctity of marital union, a theme expanded in the New Testament as an image of Christ's love for the Church (Eph. 5:25-32).

verses.text: A loving doe, a graceful deer—let her breasts satisfy you at all times; be intoxicated always in her love.
verses.comment: A poetic celebration of marital love, which also points to the biblical vision of love that is both physical and spiritual, rooted in lifelong covenant.

verses.text: Why, my son, should you be intoxicated with a forbidden woman or embrace the bosom of a stranger?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question emphasizing the value of fidelity and self-control; spiritually, it warns against idolatry and false loves (see Hos. 2:2).

verses.text: For a man’s ways are before the eyes of the LORD, and he watches all his paths.
verses.comment: God sees everything; there is no hiding from divine justice—a reminder of ongoing spiritual accountability.

verses.text: The evil deeds of a wicked man ensnare him; he is held fast in the cords of his sin.
verses.comment: Sin enslaves and binds; a spiritual parallel to New Testament teachings about the slavery of sin and the need for liberation (Rom. 6:16-18).

verses.text: He dies for lack of discipline, and because of his great folly he is lost.
verses.comment: Discipline is necessary for life; its absence results in spiritual death. This echoes the scriptural theme of salvation being found through obedience and perseverance.
